We're working on more stories right now

                                            By 
                                                    Michael D'Antonio


                                            By 
                                                    Claudio Saunt


                                            By 
                                                    T.R. Goldman


                                            By 
Todd S. Purdum


                AP Photo

            By 
Adam Sneed

10/25/15 11:47 AM EDT
The top Democrat on the House committee investigating the 2012 Benghazi attacks in Libya said on Sunday Democrats won’t leave the panel in protest.
“We have decided to stay on the committee because somebody has to be in the room to defend the truth,” Rep. Elijah Cummings of Maryland said on NBC’s “Meet The Press.”
Story Continued Below
In the run-up to Thursday’s 11-hour hearing with former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, Democrats were reported considering pulling out of the hearings that they’ve dismissed as a Republican witch hunt and a waste of taxpayer money.
But Cummings said Sunday the hearing showed that he and his Democratic colleagues still have an important role to play.
“You really did need to have Democrats in the room … to make sure the complete picture was painted,” he said.
Democrats will also keep up their efforts to make all witness testimony available to the public, Cummings said. 

2016

            By 
Glenn Thrush
             and 
Gabriel Debenedetti

While Clinton’s appearance was public and televised, dozens of witnesses have testified privately. And Cummings said transcripts of those hearings will reveal the GOP’s true intentions of hurting Clinton’s standing in her bid for the Democratic presidential nomination.
Appearing separately, Committee Chairman Trey Gowdy (R-S.C.) said private hearings are preferable for all parties and will continue.
“In the private interviews, there is never any of what you saw Thursday,” Gowdy said. Those hearings typically only go as long as one hour of questioning from both sides, “which is why you’re going to see the next two dozen interviews done privately.”
Gowdy said a public hearing was Clinton’s choice, and that led to the extensive questioning and partisan bickering. “The private ones always produce better results,” he said.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: Cummings: Dems will stay on Benghazi committee
